title: An optimized protocol to identify keratinocyte subpopulations in vitro by single-cell RNA sequencing analysis
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Cell cultivation and compound stimulation
Seeding
Timing: approximately 1 h
The procedure of the in vitro NHEKs culture is described in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]. From the seeding step, cells are cultured in a 24-well plate (surface area 1.9 cm2).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2242-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Protocol for cell culturing and stimulation of NHEKs
Protocol was designed based on our previous study.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8] Scale bars = 200 μm.
Note: The 24-well plate is used, thus consistent with the other experiments in Siriwach et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Observe cells cultured in T-25 flask under a microscope. Confirm that those cells reach a good confluency of around 70%–90%.
Prepare a 24-well culture plate.
Thaw the frozen trypsin/EDTA solution and HEPES buffer, and prewarm necessary amounts at 37°C.
Dispense 5 mL of trypsin neutralizing solution into a 15 mL-centrifuge tube and prewarm at 37°C.
Prewarm the HuMedia-KG2 medium containing 150 μM CaCal2 to 37°C. It will be used later for cell resuspension.
Remove the culture medium from the flask by aspiration.
Gently wash adherent cells with 2 mL of HEPES buffer for ∼30 s.
Remove HEPES buffer by aspiration.
Treat the cells with 2 mL of trypsin/EDTA solution for about 1 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Remove the trypsin/EDTA solution by aspiration, but leave approximately 0.5 mL of the solution. Tighten the cap to prevent cells from drying out.
Leave the flask at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Critical: Do not incubate the cells in a 37°C incubator.
Occasionally tilt the flask to spread trypsin/EDTA solution over the entire cell layer. Gently tap the side of the flask approximately every 2 min to further detach the cells.

Observe the cells under a microscope at 5–8 min after trypsinization. If attached cells could still be observed, strongly tap the side of the plate to further detach the remaining cells from the culture surface.
After confirming that cells are completely detached from the culture surface, add 5 mL of HEPES buffer, gently pipette mixing 1–2 times using a 10-mL pipette, and then collect them into the centrifuge tube containing trypsin neutralizing solution (d).
Centrifuge at 220 g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant by aspiration.
Resuspend cells with 5–8 mL of the prewarmed medium (1e) and count the number of cells with a hemocytometer.
The seeding density is 2,500 cells/cm2. Number of viable cells required for one well in 24-well plate is 2,500 × 1.9 cm2 = 4,750 cells and the medium volume per well is 500 μL. Adjust the concentration of cell suspension accordingly before transferring into the 24-well plate, 500 μL of cell suspension per well.
Close the lid and gently shake the 24-well plate to ensure even plating density.
Incubate the plate for 24 h.
Critical: At 24 h after seeding, observe the cells under a microscope. Cells should be attached and spread evenly on the culture surface in the form of single individual cells or small clusters (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Medium change
Timing: approximately 30 min
At 24 h after seeding, change the culture medium to EpiLife (Invitrogen) containing 60 μM CaCl2 (Gibco) in the absence of growth factors for 48 h.
Prewarm EpiLife containing 60 μM CaCl2 at 37°C in a water bath approximately 10–15 min.
Under aseptic conditions, discard the culture medium by aspiration and then immediately add 500 μL of EpiLife containing 60 μM CaCl2 per well.

Critical: Avoid pipette tips touching cells directly by placing the tips at the sidewall of the wells.
Put the 24-well plate back into the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator and further incubate for 48 h.
LPA stimulation
Timing: approximately 1 h
At 48 h after medium change, cells are stimulated with EpiLife, in the absence of growth factors, containing 1.2 mM CaCl2 (Gibco) and supplemented with 30 ng/mL recombinant human IL-4 in the absence or presence of 10 μM LPA for control vehicle- and LPA-conditions, respectively. Stimulation cocktails are prepared for 12 wells per each condition.
Prewarm EpiLife medium containing 1.2 mM CaCl2 at 37°C in a water bath, approximately 10–15 min beforehand.
Prepare 3 mL of the EpiLife/DMSO solution by adding 30 μL of DMSO in 2,970 μL of EpiLife medium.
Prepare 7 mL of the EpiLife/IL-4/Ca2+ by adding 3 μL of 30 ng/mL recombinant human IL-4 and 12 μL of 1 M CaCl2.
Prepare 1 mL of 100 μM LPA by dissolving 100 μL of LPA (1 mM)/HEPES with 900 μL of EpiLife/DMSO.
Prepare stimulation cocktails for LPA and control conditions.
Control condition: mixing of 1,440 μL of the EpiLife/DMSO + 3,360 μL of the EpiLife/IL-4/Ca2+= 4.8 mL in total.
LPA condition: mixing of 480 μL of 100 μM LPA + 960 μL of the EpiLife/DMSO + 3,360 μL of the EpiLife/IL-4/Ca2+ = 4.8 mL in total.
Prewarm the cocktails at 37°C in a water bath approximately 10–15 min prior to stimulation.
Place the 24-well plate in the clean bench. Under aseptic conditions, discard the culture medium by aspiration and then immediately add 500 μL of the stimulation cocktails (3e). Start from 12 wells of control condition to 12 wells of LPA condition.

Put the 24-well plate back into the 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator and further incubate for 72 h.
Prepare single-cell suspension
Timing: approximately 1 h
At 72 h post-stimulation, prepare 300 cells/μL of single-cell suspension from either control or LPA -treated conditions.
Prepare two of 1.5 mL centrifuge tubes.
Thaw the frozen trypsin/EDTA solution and HEPES buffer, and prewarm necessary amounts at 37°C.
For each condition, dispense 6 mL of trypsin neutralizing solution into a 15 mL-centrifuge tube and prewarm at 37°C.
For each condition, transfer 500 μL of the stimulating culture medium (3e) in a 1.5 mL centrifuge tube. EpiLife/DMSO/IL-4/Ca2+ for control condition and EpiLife/DMSO/IL-4/Ca2+/LPA for LPA stimulation condition.
Prewarm the medium (4d) to 37°C in a water bath. Later they will be used for cell suspension.
Remove culture medium from the 24-well plate by aspiration.
Gently wash the cells with 500 μL of HEPES buffer for about 30 s.
Remove HEPES buffer by aspiration.
Treat cells with 100 μL of trypsin/EDTA solution.
Leave the 24-well plate at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Critical: Do not incubate the cells in a 37°C incubator.
Confirm that cells detach, turn into round shape and don't form large cell aggregate under a microscope.
Five to eight mins after trypsinization, when approximately half of the cells are detached, tap the side of the plate to further detach the remaining cells from the culture surface.
After confirming that cells are completely detached from the culture surface, add 500 μL of HEPES buffer, gently pipette mixing and then collect them by combining wells of the same condition together into a 15 mL-centrifuge tube containing trypsin neutralizing solution (4c).
Centrifuge at 220 g for 5 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Discard the supernatant by aspiration.

Resuspend cells in 200 μL of the prewarmed medium (4e) and count the cell number with a hemocytometer.
Adjust the cell concentration to 300 cells/μL.
Store the cell suspension on ice.
Critical: Cell suspension should be prepared as quickly as possible before the cell capture step using the Fluidigm C1 system. As least 200 μL of cell suspension for each condition is required for subsequent steps. In our study, we used the IFC size 17–25 μm. The number of cells for loading was 600 cells.
Note: The recommendation of cell concentration is vary depending on the size of IFC. Please check the SMART-Seq® v4 Ultra® Low Input RNA Kit for the Fluidigm® C1TM System (Clontech), IFCs user manual. The protocol is available for download at https://www.takarabio.com/documents/User Manual/SMART/SMART-Seq_v4[href=https://www.takarabio.com/documents/User%20Manual/SMART/SMART-Seq_v4] (Ultra Low Input RNA Kit for the Fluidigm C1 System IFCs User Manual_032416.pdf).
Single-cell isolation, cDNA library preparation, and next generation sequencing
Timing: 3 days
The procedure of single-cell isolation, cDNA library preparation and next generation sequencing are described in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]. Conduct experiment according to the SMART-Seq® v4 Ultra® Low Input RNA Kit for the Fluidigm® C1TM System (Clontech), IFCs user manual. The protocol is available for download at https://www.takarabio.com/documents/User Manual/SMART/SMART-Seq_v4[href=https://www.takarabio.com/documents/User%20Manual/SMART/SMART-Seq_v4] (Ultra Low Input RNA Kit for the Fluidigm C1 System IFCs User Manual_032416.pdf).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2242-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Step-by-step procedure of single-cell isolation, cDNA library preparation, and next generation sequencing
Single cell suspension of 300 cells/μL from either control or LPA stimulation is loaded onto the IFC for single-cell isolation on the Fluidigm C1 Autoprep system (hereafter, C1 machine). In our study, the IFC size was 17–25 μm. Perform cell capturing according to the Fluidigm C1 protocol.
Prepare the C1 reagent mixtures.

Prewarm buffers and reagents from the C1 Single-Cell Auto Prep Reagent Kit to room temperature (20°C–25°C) prior to use. These include Cell Wash Buffer, C1 Preloading Reagent, C1 Blocking Reagent, and C1 Harvest Reagent. Thaw C1 Suspension Buffer on ice and vortex well before use.
Thaw 5× Ultra Low First-Strand Buffer.
Prepare Lysis Mix.
Prepare Reverse Transcription (RT) Mix.
Prepare PCR Mix.
Apply priming solution into the IFC according to the loading mapping in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2242-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Pipetting map
(A) Priming step.
(B) Cell loading step. Figure is generated based on the Fluidigm’s protocol “Using C1 to Generate Single-Cell cDNA Libraries for mRNA Sequencing”. Protocol is available for download at https://www.fluidigm.com/support/instrument-support/c1-support[href=https://www.fluidigm.com/support/instrument-support/c1-support].
Apply 200 μL of C1 Harvest Reagent into the inlets marked with large red circles for total 2 inlets. After application, swirl the IFC gently to distribute the reagent evenly.
Apply 20 μL of C1 Harvest Reagent into the inlets marked with red dots for total 36 inlets.
Apply 20 μL of C1 Harvest Reagent into 2 pairs of inlets marked with red dots in the middle of the outside columns for total 4 inlets.
Apply 15 μL of C1 Blocking Reagent into the inlets marked in yellow for total 2 inlets.
Peel off the white tape at the IFC bottom.
Place the IFC in to the C1 machine and press the LOAD button. Run the SMART-Seq v4: Prime (1861×/1862×/1863×) script.
When the prime run finishes, press EJECT to remove the primed IFC from the C1 machine.
Critical: Avoid bubbles in IFC by placing pipette tips at the bottom of inlets and slowly dispensing the reagents.
Prepare the LIVE/DEAD cell staining solution.
Vortex the dyes for 10 s and spin down.
Prepare the LIVE/DEAD staining solution (see LIVE/DEAD cell staining solution Table).

Freshly prepare, protect from light and store at room temperature (20°C–25°C) before use.
Vortex the solution thoroughly before transferring into the IFC.
Apply cells into the IFC according to the loading mapping in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B.
Prepare the Cell Mix by combining the cell suspension with C1 Suspension Reagent at 3:2 ratios according to the Cell Mix table. Slowly pipet up and down for thorough mixing. Do not vortex the cells. Keep the cell suspension on ice.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2242_8.csv
Freshly prepare and store on ice.
Remove blocking reagent from the IFC inlets marked in green and yellow by aspiration.
Set a pipette to 12 μL, then slowly pipet the Cell Mix up and down 5–10 times to mix thoroughly and dissociate any cell clumps.
Note: Do not vortex the Cell Mix. Avoid bubbles when mixing.
Apply 24 μL of C1 Preloading Reagent into the inlet marked in purple.
Apply 7 μL of Cell Wash Buffer into the inlet marked in pink.
Apply 10 μL of the Cell Mix into the inlet marked in green.
Note: You may pipet up to 20 μL of Cell Mix, but only 5 μL will enter the IFC.
Vortex the LIVE/DEAD staining solution well, then apply 7 μL of the solution into the inlet marked in blue.
Place the IFC into the C1 machine. Run the SMART-Seq v4: Cell Load & Stain (1861×/1862×/1863×) script.
Note: Run IFCs of control and LPA-stimulated cells in parallel on two C1 machines.
When the run finishes, press EJECT to remove the IFC from the C1 machine.
The capturing efficiency can be evaluated under a microscope and only live single cells should be used for library preparation.

Examine all 96-capture sites on the IFC using an inverted fluorescent microscope. Record the number of captured cells in each capture site. Check also the viability of the cells using LIVE/DEAD staining.
Proceed to cDNA library preparation using “SMART-Seq v4” (Clontech).
Apply Lysis Mix, Reverse Transcription and PCR reagents into the IFC according to the loading map in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2242-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Pipetting map for cell lysis, revere transcription, and PCR steps
Figure is generated based on the Fluidigm’s protocol “Using C1 to Generate Single-Cell cDNA Libraries for mRNA Sequencing”.
Discard the remaining solution in both the flow through outlet marked in yellow, and in the inlet marked in purple.
Apply 180 μL of C1 Harvest Reagent into each of the reservoirs marked with red rectangles for total 4 total reservoirs.
Apply 7 μL of Lysis Mix into the inlet marked in orange.
Apply 8 μL of Reverse Transcription (RT) Mix into the inlet marked in green.
Apply 24 μL of PCR Mix into the inlets marked in blue for total 2 inlets.
Apply 24 μL of Preloading Reagent into the inlet marked in purple.
Place the IFC into the C1 machine and run the SMART-Seq v4: Sample Prep (1861×/1862×/1863×) script. Run the script overnight (8 h).
Note: The running time is 8 h.
Critical: Harvest should be performed as soon as the Sample Prep script run finishes. Otherwise, small volumes are prone to loss by evaporation. If the elapsed time between the start of sample prep and harvest (for example, when running the script overnight) is over 8 h, adjust the finishing time in the script by sliding the orange bar in the dialog box to “Select when the script should finish.”
Harvest cDNAs from the C1 IFC.
Prewarm C1 DNA Dilution Reagent to room temperature (20°C–25°C).

When the SMART-Seq v4: Sample Prep script run completes, press EJECT to retrieve the IFC from the C1 machine.
Label a new 96-well plate “Diluted Harvest” along with the experiment name, and date.
Apply 10 μL of the C1 DNA Dilution Reagent into each well of the “Diluted Harvest” plate.
Carefully pull back the four pieces of tape covering the IFC harvesting inlets using a plastic removal tool.
Use an eight-channel pipette to transfer 3.5 μL of the harvested amplicon from each collection site according to Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] into the Diluted Harvest plate (see Harvest amplicon dilution Table).

Transfer the entire volume of C1 harvest amplicons from the IFC into each well of the diluted harvest plate containing 10 μL of C1 DNA Dilution Reagent. Follow step 1–4 in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7].

Critical: It is critical to follow the instruction map while transferring the cDNAs from the IFC to the “Diluted Harvest” plate in order to trace the sample IDs.
Seal and vortex the “Diluted Harvest” plate for 10 s at medium speed and then spin it down.
Pause point: Samples can be stored for up to one week at 4°C or at –20°C for long term.
Quantify harvested cDNAs using PicoGreen® assay.
Determine cDNA concentration.
Use Single-Cell mRNA Seq PicoGreen Template for quantifying the cDNA library.
Input values into the Concentration Estimate Table on the “Example Results” tab in the template.

Dilute each sample based on an optimal dilution determined from the Concentration Estimate Table, which should fall within the optimal range of concentrations for Nextera XT library preparation as below.
Note: The Nextera XT protocol is optimized for 1 ng of input DNA. The optimal cDNA concentration for the Nextera XT DNA Library Preparation is 0.10–0.3 ng/μL.
Label a new 96-well PCR plate as “Diluted for Sequencing.”
Apply an appropriate amount of C1 Harvest Reagent into each well of the “Diluted for Sequencing” plate according to the determined dilution (see Harvest amplicon dilution Table):

Transfer 2 μL of each harvest sample from the “Diluted Harvest” plate to the “Diluted for Sequencing” plate.
Seal the “Diluted for Sequencing” plate with adhesive film.
Vortex at medium speed for 20 s and centrifuge at 350 g for 1 min.
Perform library preparation using the Nextera XT DNA Library Preparation Kit (Illumina) and Nextera XT Index Kit (Illumina).
Note: In our study, we used the Nextera XT Index kit.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] However, a new version, V2 kit has been released. We recommend using this new kit version following the manufacturer’s instructions.
Prepare cDNA for Tagmentation.
Critical: Warm up Tagment DNA Buffer and NT Buffer to room temperature (20°C–25°C). Confirm there is no precipitation in NT Buffer. If there are any precipitates, vortex until they are completely dissolved.
After thawing, ensure all reagents are adequately mixed by gently inverting the tubes 3–5 times, followed by a brief centrifugation.
Label a new 96-well PCR plate “Library Prep.”
Prepare tagmentation premix in a 1.5 mL centrifuge tube. Calculate the required amount of the premix based on the sample number, or prepare for 96 samples (see below tables).

Freshly prepare and store on ice.

Aliquot equal amounts of the premix into each tube of an 8-tube strip.
Transfer 3.75 μL of the premix into each well of the “Library Prep” plate using an 8-channel pipette.
Transfer 1.25 μL of each diluted sample from the “Diluted for Sequencing” plate to the “Library Prep” plate.
Seal the plate and vortex at medium speed for 20 s. Centrifuge at 2,000 g for 5 min to remove bubbles.
Place the “Library Prep” plate in a hot-lid thermal cycler and run the following program:

Seal the plate and vortex at medium speed. Centrifuge at 2,000 g for 5 min.
Amplify the tagmented cDNA.
Note: Carefully read the Illumina protocol, “Nextera XT DNA Library Prep Reference Guide” for index primer selection criteria before proceeding to PCR amplification of the tagmented cDNA.
Aliquot equal volumes of Nextera PCR Master Mix (NPM) into each tube of an 8-tube strip. Calculate the required amount of NPM based on the sample number, or prepare for 96 samples (see below tables).

Apply 3.75 μL of the aliquoted NPM into each well of the “Library Prep” plate using an 8-channel pipette.

Select appropriate Index 1 (N7xx) and Index 2 (S5xx) primers required for all samples. Each Index 1 Primer corresponds to a column of the 96-well plate and each Index 2 Primer corresponds to a row. Apply 1.25 μL of Index 1 Primers (N7xx) into the corresponding wells in row A of the “Library Prep” plate using a 12-channel pipette. As a result, 12 wells in row “A” will contain different Index 1 Primers.
Note: If a 12-channel pipette is not available, use an 8-channel pipette instead.
Apply 1.25 μL of Index 2 Primers (S5xx) to the corresponding wells in column B of the “Library Prep” plate using an 8-channel pipette. As a result, each of the 8 wells in column “B” will contain different Index 2 Primers.
Seal the plate with adhesive film and vortex at medium speed for 20 s. Centrifuge at 2,000 g for 2 min.
Place the “Library Prep” plate into a thermal cycler and perform PCR amplification.

Pause point: The PCR products can be remained on the thermal cycler overnight (8 h), or be stored at 2°C–8°C for up to 2 days or at –20°C for long term.
Library pooling, cleanup, and quantification. PCR-amplified, tagmented cDNA is purified by immobilization on AMPure XP beads (Agencourt).
Note: Before starting, incubate bead aliquots at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for at least 30 min and mix well to disperse.
Determine the number of samples to be pooled based on desired sequencing depth and sequencer throughput.
Note: If preferred, samples can be cleaned up individually prior to pooling.
Incubate AMPure XP beads at room temperature (20°C–25°C) and vortex for 1 min.
Prepare the library by pipetting the appropriate volume from each sample into a 1.5-mL tube, according to the desired sample number.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2242_19.csv

Add the required amount of AMPure XP beads to the pooled library according to the table above.
Mix well by vortexing or pipetting the entire mixture up and down 5 times.
Incubate the bead mix at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 5 min to let the cDNA libraries bind to the beads.
Note: The beads are viscous. Pipette the entire volume and dispense slowly.
Spin down before placing the tube on a magnetic stand for 2 min. Confirm that supernatant appears completely clear without any beads left.
Keep the sample on the magnetic stand and discard the supernatant.
Add 180 μL of 70% ethanol without disturbing the beads, incubate for 30 s and carefully remove the supernatant. cDNA libraries will remain bound to the beads during this washing step.
Note: Prepare fresh 70% ethanol.
Repeat the above step (ix).
Spin down and place the sample again on magnetic stand for 30 s before removing all remaining ethanol with a pipette.
Allow the sample to air-dry for 10–15 min.
Critical: Be sure that the pellet after drying should look matte with no shine. Insufficient drying or over-drying may reduce the recovery yield.
Once the pellet is dry, elute the pooled, purified library by adding a required volume of C1 DNA Dilution Reagent based on the number of pooled samples.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2242_20.csv
∗C1 Dilution Reagent volume is equal to the original pool volume.
Remove the sample from the magnetic stand and vortex the tube for 3 s to mix thoroughly. Incubate at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 2 min.
Spin down and place the sample back on magnetic stand for 2 min or longer, until the solution is completely clear.
Transfer the entire volume of clear supernatant containing purified cDNA library to a new 1.5-mL centrifuge tube.
Repeat steps iv – xii.

Elute the library by adding a required volume∗ of C1 DNA Dilution Reagent according to the number of pooled samples.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2242_21.csv
∗C1 Dilution Reagent volume is 1.5 times larger than the initial library volume.
Remove the tube from the magnetic stand and vortex the tube for 3 s.
Incubate at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 2 min.
Place the tube on the magnetic stand for 2 min until the supernatant is completely clear.
Carefully transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5-mL centrifuge tube labeled as “Cleaned Lib.”
Quantify the cDNA library and check its quality using a Bioanalyzer 2100 (Agilent) with a High Sensitivity DNA kit (Agilent) in triplicate (see Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).

Figure 8. Quantitative of the single-cell cDNA library using Bioanalyzer
The representative quantification data of control NHEKs single cell cDNA library with Bioanalyzer is shown.
Refer to the “Nextera XT DNA Library Preparation Guide” to determine the appropriate library concentration for sequencing.
Proceed to next generation sequencing in single-end mode using Illumina HiSeq 2500 platform (Illumina) at the read depth of 1 million reads per cell.
Sequencing, mapping, and data analysis
Timing: approximately 1 week
Evaluate raw sequencing data using FastQC.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]
Remove adapter sequence using Cutadapt.3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Map sequence reads to the reference genome (hg38) together with the GENCODE human annotation by using STAR.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]
Generate a count matrix using featureCounts.5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]
Conduct downstream analysis using Seurat (v3.1.5) on R.6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]

Note: Cells with poor quality should be filtered out based on 3 major criteria: total count number, total detected gene number, and percentage of mitochondrial genes. Given significant batch differences in stimulated cell preparation, cDNA library preparation, and sequencing between the 2 conditions, it is critical to use a suitable batch-effect correction method to remove batch effects before further analysis. For our data, Harmony was used (v1.0).7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7] More analysis details are available in Siriwach et al.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
